posts.post_content:
Why does this card need to make sense? You guys don't usually give a damn about flavour anyways.

posts.post_content:
I really don't like the fact that the two sides have nothing to do with each other, especially since the archer side is so mechanically-driven.
  
   
Either
  
Shoots flying creature for 2 -> shoots any creature for 2
  
or
  
Shoots flying creature for 2 -> shoots flying creature for 5
  
   
would have made the card more connected as a whole. As is, it's a mess of a card.

Posted By: Tanaka348 (9/23/2011 3:14:16 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
Makes sense to me... as a human archer, she hunts down evasive (flying) prey and deals damage equal to her "base" power; as a werewolf, she hunts down elusive prey (which are trying to avoid any chance of combat with her) and deals damage equal to her total power.  
  
It actually speaks a good deal about the difference between otherwise similar humans and werewolves. Humans use weapons which augment their abilities, but are still limited (no amount of [ferocity](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=ferocity) will make the ranger's arrow's deadlier), while werewolves use their feral abilities and are willing to get their hands dirty for the extra killing power.
posts.html:
Makes sense to me... as a human archer, she hunts down evasive (flying) prey and deals damage equal to her "base" power; as a werewolf, she hunts down elusive prey (which are trying to avoid any chance of combat with her) and deals damage equal to her total power.

It actually speaks a good deal about the difference between otherwise similar humans and werewolves. Humans use weapons which augment their abilities, but are still limited (no amount of ferocity will make the ranger's arrow's deadlier), while werewolves use their feral abilities and are willing to get their hands dirty for the extra killing power.

This makes sense to me too... As a ranger, he runs around outside hunting... With human tools, yes, but he's a hunter. Night falls, and he keeps going, with different tools though.

Posted By: Anubisisking (10/1/2011 1:56:36 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
It makes perfect sense to me, people just whine too much.
  
Stop thinking about it as a Ranger or Archer, and think of her as a Hunter. As a human, she's limited to relying on her bow, which is traditionally used to hit arial creatures. As a werewolf, she still retains her hunting prowess, but it's enhanced by the wolves natural skills - since it no longer needs the bow, it hunts creatures on a one-on-one, predatorial basis.
posts.html:
It makes perfect sense to me, people just whine too much.
Stop thinking about it as a Ranger or Archer, and think of her as a Hunter. As a human, she's limited to relying on her bow, which is traditionally used to hit arial creatures. As a werewolf, she still retains her hunting prowess, but it's enhanced by the wolves natural skills - since it no longer needs the bow, it hunts creatures on a one-on-one, predatorial basis.
